stem: An 89-year-old client from a long-term care facility is admitted for 'not acting like himself.' He is confused and cool to the touch. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status decline in an elderly client.
Background: Chronic indwelling catheter for neurogenic bladder. History of stroke.
Assessment: Client is stuporous. Heart rate is thready. Urine in the bag is cloudy and malodorous.
Recommendation: Consider immediate sepsis protocol activation.

tabs.title: Geriatric Infection Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Core Temperature95.8°F (35.4°C)Hypothermia
Lactate Level3.9 mmol/LElevated
Mental StatusCAM+: Acute DeliriumAltered mental status
WBC Count4,200/µLWithin normal limits

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/52 mmHg, HR 108 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 95.8°F (35.4°C), SpO2 91%.

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV warm fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics as prescribed.
Obtain blood and urine cultures immediately (before antibiotics).
Administer PO ibuprofen to treat the underlying inflammation.
Place the client in Trendelenburg position to improve BP.

parameterOptions.text: Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) and level of consciousness
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs of Geriatric Septic Shock (c2). Elderly patients often present with atypical signs of infection, such as acute confusion (delirium), hypothermia (95.8°F), and hypotension. The elevated lactate (3.9 mmol/L) further supports the diagnosis of shock. Priority actions include obtaining cultures (a2) before initiating rehydration and antibiotics (a1). Monitoring should include MAP (p1) and lung sounds (p2) due to the risk of fluid overload during resuscitation.
clinicalPearls: Hypothermia (< 96.8°F) in a septic patient can be a more concerning sign than fever.
Cloudy/malodorous urine in an elderly patient with acute confusion should raise suspicion for urosepsis.
The 'cold' presentation in elderly patients can be attributed to an aging hypothalamus and blunted immune response.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the patient does not have an infection because the WBC count (4,200/µL) is within normal limits.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In elderly patients with sepsis, the WBC count may remain normal or even decrease (leukopenia). Rely on other indicators such as MAP, lactate, and mental status.

mnemonic.title: COLD Sepsis
mnemonic.expansion: C-Confusion, O-Out of range (Cold) Temp, L-Low BP, D-Delirium
